answer_html: \(\int x\arctan(x)\, dx=\arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{2}\arctan(x) + C\) completing the question.
answer_latex: $\int x\arctan(x)\, dx=\arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{2}\arctan(x) + C$ completing the question.
hints_html:
Notice that \(\arctan(x)\) has an easy derivative. How can we exploit this?

Try starting with integration by parts.

A clever last trick is to note that \(x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1\)
hints_latex:
Notice that $\arctan(x)$ has an easy derivative. How can we exploit
this?
Try starting with integration by parts.
A clever last trick is to note that $x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1$
hints_raw:
Notice that <math> \arctan(x) </math> has an easy derivative. How can we exploit this?
Try starting with integration by parts.
A clever last trick is to note that <math> x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1 </math>
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
For the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int x\arctan(x)\, dx,\end{aligned}\]

we start by using integration by parts. Let

\[\begin{aligned} u = \arctan(x) \quad & \quad v = \frac{x^{2}}{2} \\ du = \frac{dx}{1 + x^{2}} \quad & \quad dv = xdx\end{aligned}\]

This gives

\[\begin{aligned} \int x\arctan(x)\, dx = \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx\end{aligned}\]

To evaluate the last integral, we use the fact that \(x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1\) to see that

\[\begin{aligned} \int x\arctan(x)\, dx &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\ &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{1 + x^{2} - 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\ &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int\, dx + \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{ 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\ &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{2}\arctan(x) + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
For the integral

:<math>
\int x\arctan(x)\, dx,
</math>

we start by using integration by parts. Let 

:<math>
\begin{align}
u = \arctan(x) \quad & \quad v = \frac{x^{2}}{2} \\
du = \frac{dx}{1 + x^{2}} \quad & \quad dv = xdx
\end{align}
</math> 

This gives

:<math>
\int x\arctan(x)\, dx = \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx
</math>

To evaluate the last integral, we use the fact that <math> x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1 </math> to see that

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int x\arctan(x)\, dx &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{1 + x^{2} - 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int\, dx + \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{ 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{2}\arctan(x) + C
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answer and show all your work. Simplification of the answer is not required.

Evaluate the following integral:

\[\begin{aligned} \int x \tan^{-1}x\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

Note: tan-1(x) is also denoted by arctan(x).
statement_latex:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

Evaluate the following integral:

\begin{align*}
\int x \tan^{-1}x\,dx.
\end{align*}

Note: tan\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{x}) is also denoted by
arctan(\emph{x}).
statement_raw:
'''Full-Solution Problem.''' Justify your answer and '''show all your work.''' Simplification of the answer is not required.

Evaluate the following integral:
:<math>
\int x \tan^{-1}x\,dx.
</math>

Note: tan<sup>-1</sup>(''x'') is also denoted by arctan(''x'').
